150995861.review:
So I just finished this game, and I am literally crying right now. What an amazing game made by Telltale Games. I loved the first part, and this, and both games made me cry. Some of the choices are really difficult to choose. I didn't know anything about The Walking Dead before playing this and the first part of the game. I am glad devs made this wonderful game. The graphics of the game are good, the story, music, characters-everything is amazing!

While playing the first episode, the part where [spoiler]Clementine stitches her dog-bitten wound[/spoiler], I could literally feel that pain. After that scene, I was not feeling well. I felt like I had a vehicular accident and was feeling dizzy. Later, I went to sleep. Really, that scene was very powerful as well as disturbing too. I know it's just a game, but it left me speechless. I have seen many cruel and disturbing scenes in video games, but this was something else.

This is not just a game, it's a movie. I want to thank all the people who were involved in making this game, especially all the voice actors. They literally gave life to all the characters. This game made me want to watch The Walking Dead series.
Absolutely a 10/10 game. Worth every penny.

Realmente es muy lindo juego, en los cuales cada episodio está cargado de buen contenido y vale TOTALMENTE la pena, tanto como la temporada 1. Osea... está en "extremadamente positivas" y eso ya debería decir mucho de sí mismo.

Sin embargo, algo malo es que requiere de un parche para traducirse, y es sorprendente que los de Telltale no hayan dado el juego traducido digitalmente, y pues el idioma al español lo tenemos gracias a los archivos de la versión física del juego. No es algo que tome mucho tiempo, pero cuando vi el menú principal en inglés y no haber encontrado una opción para cambiar el lenguaje del juego, fue sorprendente. Pero bueno, al final lo disfruto bastante.

Me esperaba una configuración gráfica amplia como la del primer juego, y una mejor calidad visual pero no la hubo, parece lucir exactamente igual que la temporada 1. Sin embargo, no digo que es un punto negativo, solo digo cosas que me esperaba pero no había. En fin, gran serie la de The Walking Dead, la recomiendo bastante!

149536998.review:
"Seems like we always wanna talk about the end, don't we?"

[i]The Walking Dead: Season Two[/i] is an episodic adventure video game developed and published by Telltale Games.

[b]Story[/b]
Playing first Season is pretty much a requirement to play Season Two.

Season Two of The Walking Dead takes place shortly after events from first game.
You step into the shoes of Clementine, who after final occurrences in last episode in Season One, ventures together with Omid and Christa to shelter known as Wellington all the way up north, protecting from walkers due cold and layers of snow. Unfortunately Clem soon finds herself alone, having to utilize everything she was taught to survive, facing threat from undead and humans on her journey to reach safe haven.

[b]Gameplay[/b]
Just like previous season, S2 is a point-and-click adventure game where you control your character through a series of episodes, gameplay playing second fiddles to narrative and story.
Most of the time is spend on selecting different dialogue options and in few moments, making important choices that affect the narrative, with consequences coming back later to bite you.
When not chatting Walking Dead offers you an option to explore small sized areas. You can find and interact with items, pick them up and keep for later use, make a quick observation about them or chat with characters.
Game has more than a few Quick Time Events to create intense action focused bits so be prepared for button mashing or quick selection of what to press with somewhat new "Hold a mouse button and drag your mouse into specific direction" to spice things up!

At the end of each episode you get a screen showing off your most important choices and how overall community picked to see if you are in majority or minority. Though I'm pretty sure with Telltale Games problems, servers are down so you have look at data from...some time period.

[b]Playtime and replayability[/b]
It took me 8 hours to make my way through all episodes.
You can give game another go to check how different choices impact the narrative.

[b]Pros and cons[/b]
Without any doubt my favourite and simply best part of S2 is Clementine and her development as season goes on. Following her journey as she finds herself once again between a rock and a hard place, with new group facing same issues she saw before, needing to adapt as constant threat from undead and other humans give them no rest is a real treat and strongest aspect of the game. Struggle, survival, sacrifice, tough decisions and betrayals, looming hope and despair on the horizon, constant tension, game has it all. One does have to roll eyes a bit when game is putting so much emphasis on a single child in groups with multiple adult characters, as Clementine will be send to do...literally everything, but that's just protagonist curse.

Solid characters surrounding our heroine are as important to creating good narrative experience. Majority of them is well written, with variety of personalities clashing in to offer intense moments as Clem will have to find herself on some side of the barricade sooner or later.
Unfortunately they still suffer from horror syndrome where not all actions make logical sense or just plain stupid deaths to push story forward exist, and there are characters who have rather weird, questionable motives which do bring down the quality of a game down a bit. Writing also has weaker moments in the middle of the season.
And classic "choices and consequences" is a bit...iffy. I understand what they went with in 1st Season but in S2 choices feel even less impactful than before.

There is not much to be said about gameplay. It works with no problems, additional new "mouse dragging" mechanic to spice things up somewhat is a good move though, again, Walking Dead is not a game one plays for its exciting gameplay. Unfortunately game doesn't offer same amount of hub areas like first title, and that is by far biggest negative when it comes to this chunk of Season Two. 

[b]Conclusion[/b]
While slightly dropping in quality in comparison to first season, fantastic atmosphere, great cast of characters with our protagonist on top and constant tension make Season Two worth playing. 

Feel free to check out [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/31947302/] my curator page [/url] for more reviews!

149241320.review:
The Walking Dead series by Telltale Games delivers yet another emotionally charged and unforgettable experience. As we rejoin the story from the previous instalment, the stakes are even higher, creating an emotional rollercoaster that captivates players from start to finish.

The Walking Dead Season 2 is not just a game; it's a cinematic masterpiece that immerses players in a heart-wrenching narrative. The storytelling in this series continues to demonstrate the power of choice and consequence in a way that few games can match.

The characters you've grown attached to return, and your decisions impact their fates and the story's direction. This creates a sense of investment in the characters and their struggles that few games can achieve.

As the tension escalates, the game maintains its gripping narrative and appropriate soundtrack, providing an immersive experience that takes storytelling in games to new heights. Despite the undead apocalypse backdrop, it's the human elements, the relationships, and the choices that drive the narrative forward.

If you enjoyed the first season of The Walking Dead, Season 2 is a must-play continuation of the story. For those who appreciate profound storytelling, emotional depth, and memorable characters, this game is a gem in the gaming world.

In summary, The Walking Dead Season 2 is not just a game but a compelling journey that explores the depths of human emotion and the consequences of choice in a post-apocalyptic world.

147525545.review: The Walking Dead: Season Two is an exceptional continuation of the critically acclaimed series, delivering another intense and emotionally charged adventure set in the post-apocalyptic world of the undead. The game's narrative is its strongest aspect, with a gripping storyline that keeps you on the edge of your seat from start to finish. The choices you make throughout the game truly matter, impacting the relationships you form with the characters and shaping the direction of the plot. The writing is top-notch, filled with poignant moments, unexpected twists, and moral dilemmas that force you to make tough decisions. The character development in season 2 is remarkable, especially when it comes to Clementine. As a young survivor, she faces numerous challenges and dangers, and it's fascinating to witness her growth and resilience as she navigates this harsh world. The supporting characters are also well-written and fleshed out, each with their own motivations and flaws. The gameplay mechanics remain similar to the season 1, with a focus on exploration, puzzle-solving, and decision-making. The point-and-click interface is intuitive and easy to navigate, allowing for seamless immersion into the game's world. The quick-time events add a sense of urgency and tension to the gameplay, making every encounter with walkers or other survivors incredibly intense. In conclusion, The Walking Dead: Season Two is a must-play for fans of the series and anyone who appreciates a well-crafted narrative-driven game. It successfully builds upon the first season's success, delivering an emotionally charged journey that will leave you eagerly anticipating the next season. Prepare to make tough choices, forge alliances, and face the harsh realities of the zombie apocalypse in this captivating and immersive adventure.

147324534.review:
Segundo análisis que hago, en todos hay [SPOILERS INCLUIDOS]; esta vez tendré el honor de analizar una gran continuación de una aventura gráfica redonda: The Walking Dead: Temporada Dos.
He de decir que las aventuras gráficas/películas interactivas es mi género favorito (tengo mis razones), y que me gustó más la segunda temporada que la primera (oh dios mío eres un bicho raro.. Ejem, un respeto señores, todos tenemos algo raro en nuestra vida), ya sea porque empaticé aún mejor con Clementine o porque en general el nuevo grupo me gustó más (soy raro, lo sé). En fin, sin más dilación, mi análisis.

HISTORIA: The Walking Dead: Season Two es la continuación directa de la primera temporada, que a su vez fue el juego que le dió fama definitivamente a Telltale Games. La historia, a mi parecer (y el de la mayoría), es el punto más importante en una aventura gráfica.
Continuamos con las andaduras de Clementine, una niña que pierde al grupo en el que viajaba y que también pierde a su mayor amistad en el juego, Lee Everett. A partir de ese momento, Clementine tendrá que viajar con otro grupo y reencontrarse con su antiguo compañero Kenny.
Una historia que en algunos momentos noté vacía, que le faltaba algo, que morían los personajes porque así lo querían los desarrolladores. Aún así, me parece muy buena, y que hayan buenos juegos de zombies es bueno, bien porque hay muchos y empiezan a cansar o bien porque no innovan nada (ejem ejem Dead Island Riptide ejem ejem).
Le doy 4/5 estrellas.

JUGABILIDAD: Es una aventura gráfica (Regreso al Futuro, The Wolf Among Us..), así que no esperes "aplastar botones".
Es un juego generalmente pausado, con un ritmo digno de TWD, donde conocer y entablar amistad con los personajes y sobrevivir es lo importante. Aunque eso no quita que haya muchos momentos en los que correr "a toda hostia" con el botoncito. Las decisiones son variadas y los momentos en que escoger "decisiones importantes" están bien elegidos (aunque odio que un personaje muera sí o sí, pero qué se le hará...).
Le doy 5/5 estrellas.

GRÁFICOS: Es una aventura gráfica con un apartado gráfico más que excelente, que no busca (ni de lejos) la "foto-realidad" pero que no cojea en las expresiones faciales y el aspecto de los personajes y el entorno; aunque he de quejarme de esas animaciones robóticas, no me gustaron para nada. Aparte, tiene un apartado artístico muy bueno y que encaja a la perfección con la temática Zombie.
Le doy 4.5/5 estrellas.

SONIDO: Me pareció correcto, bien localizado en los momentos exactos, pero me pareció mejor la de la primera temporada. Aún así, sigue siendo correcta.
Le doy 4/5 estrellas.

INNOVACIÓN: El apartado polémico, el apartado del cáncer, el apartado de la baja nota... Llámalo como quieras. Total decepción, así describo este apartado. Ninguna evolución respecto a la primera temporada, es exactamente lo mismo. No pido que saquen lo más de lo más, pero macho, tela. A pesar de todo, todo lo aplicado en la primera temporada aquí sigue siendo excelente, y esto es lo que salva este apartado.
Le doy 2.5/5 estrellas.

NOTA FINAL: 20.5/25 estrellas = 8.5/10.

Es... Dificil de explicar. Principalmente, es un juegazo; no es malo, ni mucho menos. Gráficamente es mejor que el anterior y es mucho más largo, Sin embargo...

Debido a que el juego seguramente buscaba dejar en claro que la trama era que Clem quedaba sola con AJ, como icono de lo tanto que se sacrificó para llegar al final, el transcurso es complicado: Kenny lentamente se transforma y, si bien lo elegí porque ya me ví mil rutas de este juego en Youtube cuando era niño, ciertamente creo que estaba perdiendo el control. Luke era joven, fuerte y valiente, pero por eso mismo cometía errores y era imprudente. Sarah fue salvada tanto para morir de una forma que creo fue estúpida, y la misteriosa conclusión del resto del grupo me disgustó (peca de que, como el juego anterior, los personajes pecan de cometer muchos errores siendo que ya llevaban como 5 años en el apocalipsis)

El juego busca hacerte sentir mal en todo momento para que sepas que tu decisión fue tuya y afectará de todas formas a la historia. Todo se va a la mierda todo el tiempo y demasiado rápido, lo que no te da optimismo de un futuro hasta el bendito final (pero como siempre, algo empeora)

Considero que es mejor comprar la Definitive Series. No es un mal juego, pero sin duda alguna no la pasé bien de ninguna forma (lo cual es seguro que tenía la intensión el juego de ser).

[h3][b]Второй сезон, который самый шедевральный на мой взгляд всей серии TWD[/b][/h3]

 [b]Второй сезон на мой взгляд самый лучший среди серий. Всё дело в том, как именно раскрывается Клементина. В первом сезоне никто её за угрозу не воспринимал, ведь это всего лишь маленькая напуганная девочка, что она может сделать? Второй сезон как раз таки нам показывает, на что способна Клементина, та самая маленькая девочка. 
 
[h3][b] Геймплейная часть. [/b][/h3]

 Геймплей второго сезона остается схожим с первым сезоном. Мы принимаем решения и выбираем диалоги, которые влияют на ход сюжета. В игре есть интерактивные элементы и головоломки, дополняющие геймплей. В общем, тоже самое, только интерфейс другой.

[h3][b]Визуальное исполнение и атмосфера.[/b][/h3]

  Визуальное исполнение остается в высоком качестве, передавая атмосферу зомби-апокалипсиса. Дизайн локаций и персонажей продолжает быть проработанным и живописным. Звуковое сопровождение и музыка создают ужасающую атмосферу.

[h3][b]Заключение[/b][/h3]

    Второй сезон "The Walking Dead" продолжает успешную формулу первого сезона, предлагая увлекательную историю с сложными персонажами и моральными дилеммами. Моя оценка 10/10. Рекомендую к прохождению.

Una obra maestra para la narrativa de los videojuegos. Dentro reseña!


Point and click que sigue a su antecesor siendo esta vez Clementine la protagonista con el legado que Lee le dejó. Ahora, algo más adulta debe seguir avanzando y sobreviviendo a todo tipo de situaciones.  Poca innovación, las mismas mecánicas donde el eje principal se basa en las decisiones que tomamos y las que llevarán a un camino u otro con muertes de personajes o salvándolos.

A día de hoy se sigue conservando bien en todos los aspectos y aunque para muchos fue el cierre de la historia, continuará en otras dos temporadas de las que ya hablaremos. Un cierre perfecto durante los 5 episodios (~2 horas cada uno).  Las situaciones si bien algunas son parecidas a las del anterior juego, innova en localizaciones y personajes, donde odiarás a unos y amarás a otros. Es la segunda vez que lo juego y no ha bajado la calidad con la que lo recuerdo.

En fin si simplemente os gustan las buenas historias deberíais jugar a todas las temporadas de TWD. Poco más que decir. Gracias por leer! <3

143174087.review: La segunda temporada continúa poco después de donde terminó la primera y esta vez jugarás como Clementine en lugar de Lee. Ver el mundo a través de los ojos de una niña pequeña inmediatamente hace que el juego se sienta más deprimente y sin esperanza, ya que ahora tiene que valerse por sí misma. Los zombis, que se sintieron bastante débiles en la primera temporada, de repente son una amenaza mucho más peligrosa para Clementine también. Acá, Clem conoce a nuevos sobrevivientes y trata de mantenerse con vida con ellos, al igual que vimos en la temporada 1, pero hay nuevos desafíos que tiene que soportar en su viaje, ([spoiler]también se reencuentra con un viejo amigo que va a ser muy importante en esta historia[/spoiler]), su desarrollo como personaje acá es probablemente lo mejor que tiene este juego. Tiene 4 finales diferentes, que decidirán cómo Clem pasó 2 años de su vida. Hubo algunos cambios menores en la interfaz que mejoraron la experiencia y se sintieron muy bien una vez que me acostumbré a ellos. También la temporada 2 pareció hacer un punto para entrar directamente en la acción con un poco menos de enfoque en el tiempo de inactividad. El tono del juego se mantuvo muy parecido al de la temporada 1. A pesar de que estás jugando como la Clementine de 11 años, Telltale no tuvo ningún golpe en la historia y muchas de las situaciones en las que te colocan pueden ser muy inquietantes. Definitivamente pude ver la diferencia en el personaje, y cómo ha crecido como sobreviviente, con toda la inocencia de un niño normal de su edad desaparecido.

143166458.review:
The second season of this series follows the original in terms of what you can expect. It manages to tell a mostly equally engaging story with tonnes of interesting new characters and predicaments. 

Thankfully the gameplay elements have been largely improved, with much more polished character controls and tooltips, as well as no performance issues.

Whilst it mostly follows a similar trend to the original, where choices are largely meaningless, the game has a multitude of endings. This makes your final decisions have weight based on what you decide based on your personal experience with this story and it's characters, making it feel much more impactful.

8.5 / 10

The sequel does not leave anything to be desired, it has a more dynamic unfolding and has a better interface than its predecessor.

I had some problems with the commands (via xbox controller) interfering with the keyboard and mouse. Easy to fix but a patch for that would make the experience perfect!

Regarding the story, I'm sure its unfolding will satisfy and surprise just like the first game. I felt a greater emphasis on drama and classic zombie apocalypse situations were certainly used as a reference.

Importing my saves mentioned in the review of the original, I had some pretty cool changes regarding the characters! I finished the game twice and felt a big difference in the conclusion of the story.

I can say that the second game has aged well and runs ok! As I don't have the others here on Steam, I can't rate them here on the platform. But the other games in the series are well crafted and deserve their space in a marathon!

I didn't mention it in the first review but in this one I won't miss the opportunity to say that the voice acting and the quality of the sound effects show how fundamental this is for a quality product. Even without any EQ function the audio is super balanced and has no errors. Like phrase failures, delay in subtitles or something like that.

And just like the first game, this one runs super well on any low-end computer.

Yet with every struggle she persists, which is what makes this game so good for me. She's a fighter, and this season really shows her progress as a skilled survivor. That and how good the sound design (?) is, excellently emphasising the emotions that certain scenes invoke, such as grief from losing a loved one, or finding solidarity with a fellow survivor. 141714845.review:
Telltale's The Walking Dead season 2 is the weakest of the franchise in my opinion, and lacks in what made the prequel so good when it first came out.

Firstly, the HUD has been remade since the previous and now uses wheels instead of scrolling and the NUM pad. The dialogue box change was nice, but it is clear the selection buttons were designed with console in mind as it works great for joysticks. But for us PC players it can be more annoying than using the scroll wheel as we did in the previous game. 

Secondly, the story is very meh. Very little of what you do actually matters. Which is a problem for the entire Telltale series, but in this season it is by-far the worst. You will save characters only for them to die 20 minutes later, sometimes in the exact same episode. Several character development attempts go absolutely nowhere and characters are forgotten by other characters shortly after their dramatic death scenes. Characters also feel rushed, with them changing their personality frequently.

Clementine is an awesome character but making her the protagonist at only 11 years old really limited what the player could do compared to Lee in the previous game. There was very little of the dramatic choices or action scenes seen in the first season.

This season also fails to take into consideration a lot of what happened in the previous season. Despite the option to use save data from the previous season, this is only used in a few dialogue options in the first episode this season. The game assumes that your version of Lee went down the path of being a saint, with disregard if the player made hostile or bad choices throughout their time playing season 1.

If you're desperate for more of the TWD, this game might satisfy that urge. Otherwise, you'll probably enjoy Season 1 or Season 3-4 better than this one.

[h1] "Killing one in order to save many is... part of survival. It's one of the though decisions a weaker person couldn't make. It's why it falls to people like us to lead them to safety. They are weak and we are strong..." [/h1]

This game is a perfect continuation of the first part of the series. In terms of drama, brutality, and hard decision making, it's safe to say that the game completely lived up to my expectations.

Once again, I want to note the irreversibility and unexpectedness with which the characters die. You are just beginning to get to know someone, get used to and empathize with them, and then immediately, for sometimes completely idiotic reasons, a character dies... It's really hard to relive, but that's what makes the game so natural and stark.

Definitely recommend it for a playthrough. 10 out of 10

139403711.review:
Episodes 1-3 are great to amazing, but the last two episodes suffer from multiple rewrites and last minute changes behind the scenes that make you wish that each episode (including the first three) were given more time to cook before being published. Multiple characters have a lot of potential and you can tell that they had individual arcs planned out for each one, but by the end of the game, those same characters end up being killed off too early or just completely sidelined before getting killed off. That's not to say that there isn't some amazing characters here that do have some good fuckin arcs, one character in particular, but I don't want to give out any spoilers.

There was also the opportunity to expand on the extra DLC episode from the 1st season, but only one of the characters from it plays a big role in this season (and they're not even that good of a character), and the rest only get 10 second cameos, depending on who you took with you to the camp.

Still an amazing game, but it could've been even better. In fact, it could've been as good, if not even better than the first season.

9/10

139001276.review: I would like to start the review by saying that there will be very few spoilers in it, but it is impossible to do without them. The second season of The Walking Dead is a real kaleidoscope of failures, in spite of which the characters survive and increasingly lose their moral compass. After the woeful first season, which, however, inspired optimism, the second is seen as a standard of despair and despondency. Even when the heroes finally find their target - what do they do? They wallow in internal strife and firmly, greedily hold on to their vices. Kenny - the embodiment of responsibility - developed much more complicated, much brighter than the central character Clementine. In the first season, he lost everything and has now turned from a determined flowering man into an indifferent, grief-stricken figure who has lost the meaning of life. He has become cruel, rude, harsh and demands complete submission, because he knows better how to save your troubled asses. On the opposite side, there is the concept of independence, which acquires new facets of meaning in the dead world. The lively girl Jane is the personification of freedom. Jane experienced a lot, lost her sister, but she learned a lesson from her troubles completely different from other heroes. The key to survival is loneliness, partners are a burden that pulls you to the bottom, and any group is doomed to collapse and death. This confrontation in the second season was key. Mutual assistance, disastrous heroism and the mythical walled city of Wellington, a guiding star for Kenny and his rare supporters, on the one hand, and bitter freedom from responsibility, on the other. I really liked the game. Even more than the first part. I advise you to play it. It is worth your time. In the end, I would like to say, try to make the right decisions. In the game, as in life, even inaction has consequences.

137343234.review:
PROS: 
*Clementine is awesome
*I like the artstyle
*Some of the characters are ok I guess.
*Besides the death of [spoiler]Luke[/spoiler] episode 5 was a pretty good episode.
*[spoiler]Kenny's character[/spoiler] was great. He became a complete monster and it was really sad. 
*[spoiler]Kenny vs Jane is a tough decision. I personally chose Kenny but he's pretty fucked too.[/spoiler]
*Edgy/aggressive dialogue options are incredibly entertaining.

CONS: 
*Your choices are one sided and there is usually a better one. (they hold no weight unlike in s1 where they each affected the game in little ways)
*Dialogue options barely affect your relationships with characters. Being an asshole or saint doesn't matter because the characters forget a minute later.
*Carver is a generic power dynamic villain
*The adults make Clementine do the adult work which makes sense from a game play perspective but its really dumb.
*There is almost no downtime to just talk to the characters and get to know them. Fast paced set piece to set piece.
*Characters are killed off without finishing their arcs which is super unsatisfying. (they had the potential to be great but it was squandered)
*Barely any branching dialogue options compared to Season 1
*Saving characters doesn't matter because they don't have any redemption or development afterwards. (unlike Ben from season 1)
*Christa is M.I.A. (she never appears again in season 3 or 4)
*Bad implementation of 400 Days by giving the characters brief cameos (400 Days was supposed to be the bridge between season 1 and 2)
*Much more of an on rails experience than season 1. Its like one long interactive cut scene unlike s1 which gave you downtime and optional dialogue.

I would only recommend it on sale just to see how the story continues. You might really like it. You could also watch a play through from your favorite youtuber. 

5/10

136133944.review:
Got this in a humble from a long while back.
I have a lot more attached to this season than Season 1. I would still consider S1 the better overall season as that gave choices more impact and a tight story.
This gets a little sloppy. 
Episode 1 is a decent start with some good moments, but I think it trailed off a bit too much for its own good.
Episode 2 is better since we have a main cast now, but the number quickly rises. There are a lot of moving parts and it goes back to an earlier plot point and has it as a cliffhanger.
Episode 3 is my personal favorite. It is tight and has some great scenes overall. I was finally getting used to the main cast of characters and they were being used in the right ways.
Episode 4 is not bad at all and has some good theme progression. It is also the big episode that establishes something that will be used for the rest of the franchise. 
Episode 5 is okay. It has decent tension but I really felt the absence of the main cast. Too many were killed off and I think there could've been something more for them. The final choice is tough... especially when two of the obvious ones don't feel right. *obv i won't mention who exactly got killed but this is Walking dead. we all know people are gonna die.

I think what gets me here is how dark the story actually is. It is used well in some areas and not in others. It went for something a little different. I really appreciate that.

135939247.review:
The Walking Dead season 2 by Telltale Games is like a zombie that's been brought back to life with a whole new level of intensity.

But let's be honest, the storytelling in this game is more gripping than a zombie's grip on a fresh brain. The choices you make as Clementine will have you second-guessing yourself like a survivor second-guessing a shortcut through a zombie-infested alleyway.

And let's not forget the characters. They're more memorable than a group of survivors holed up in a prison. From the lovable goofball Luke to the sinister Carver, this game has characters that will stay with you long after the credits roll (or the zombies eat you).

Overall, The Walking Dead season 2 by Telltale Games is a game that bites back. It's the perfect mix of heart-wrenching drama, tough choices, and heart-stopping action.

7/10. Not a bad game. I would rate it as mid especially in comparison to season 1.

There are still those moments that bring me back to the joys of the first season. For the majority of the game, I was truly invested and immersed. I was digging the new cast of characters too at first.

I'll try not to spoil things, but I think we all know people are gonna die in a TWD game. Unlike the first season, the character deaths felt sloppy and like a punch to the face. Not dropping any names but a specific character in my play-through died and no one says a WORD about it, for the rest of the game!!

But overall. . .
Don't let my ranting deter you from playing. It was great wrapping up Clementine's story-line, and most of the game is fun. If you're a fan of the genre and of Clementine just play it.

132553550.review:
The Walking Dead: Season 2 by Telltale Games is a true masterpiece of storytelling. This point and click adventure game takes players on an emotional rollercoaster through the post apocalyptic world of the walking dead.

The character development in this game is simply phenomenal. The player takes on the role of Clementine, a young survivor of the zombie outbreak, and helps guide her through the difficult choices and challenges she faces. The relationships she forms with other characters are complex and nuanced, and the choices the player makes have real consequences that ripple throughout the rest of the story.

The graphics in The Walking Dead: Season 2 are stunning, with a unique art style that perfectly captures the grim and oppressive atmosphere of the world. The voice acting is top-notch, with each character bringing depth and emotion to their performances.

But what really sets this game apart is its masterful storytelling. The writers have woven a gripping tale that is equal parts heart-wrenching and thrilling, with twists and turns that will keep players on the edge of their seats. The game's choice based mechanics make every play through a unique experience, and the player's choices truly matter in shaping the story.

In conclusion, The Walking Dead: Season 2 is an absolute must play for fans of the zombie genre and anyone who appreciates a well crafted story.

132098319.review:
This season shows the problems of mixing short episodes that have to quickly change locations while telling a story with a genre where writers often feel like you have to kill people all the time. You will be thinking, "that was interesting how will this character grow from this, will they start causing problems for the group, are they going to grow and learn, never mind move the story along they're dead."

Throughout the first season you always had Lee and Clementine and could see how they grew as characters and how their relationship changed over time. In this you frequently have characters not around in certain episodes, join late, or leave. Characters are said to possess certain traits that you don't really see, and get killed off instead of finishing any kind of story arc. In the first game you had Lee's relationship with Clementine, Lee trying to earn the groups trust, Clementine trying to find her parents, Ben feeling guilty over his actions leading to the death of people, Kenny forgiving Ben. Important characters from the first season are quickly removed from the game and even after years of zombies being around the characters you are with and more incompetent than ever. Characters from the 400 Days DLC are only given a short possible cameo with the exception of one. Choices still don't really mean anything, now amounting to little more than keeping an uninteresting character alive a little longer only to have them almost immediately killed off in a scene or killed off screen. 

The focus tries to be Clementine and what living in a world like this could turn her into, even having the cliche badly written moment of random villain you hardly know saying that you are just like him, even though you might not have ever done anything for that to even make sense. You also never end up needing to make any kind of difficult decisions that you could see causing Clementine to turn into a more harsh or violent person, making the central focus of the story often non existent. The final chapter is terrible, starting like an old serial film that seems to ignore the last chapters ending where pretty much everyone should have been dead, characters start to ignore or barely be effected by being shot, and choosing one of the two endings, pairs you with an extremely abusive person, and undoes a character arc of the previous season and ends up leading to a pretty ridiculous fairy tale seeming situation which would seem to be telling people that hanging out with violent controlling abusive people is good actually (which will be undone in as ridiculous a fashion as any other ending you get in the next season opening anyway). Zombies are also supposed to be slowed down by the cold but seem to function very well after being trapped under the ice of a frozen lake. It ends up being a much more uninteresting generic zombie story full of bad cliches than the first season with some horrible and somewhat offensive use of certain characters.

131529523.review:
About the game. Follows the first one, a mix of point and click with some scenes with a bit more of action (probably more than the first). Good story. 

On Steam Deck:
- Running fine to the day of the review (will edit if I notice anything odd)
- Some blocky shadows that black out parts of the screen. Tried applying Proton GE (7.47 at the moment) and added "-noblur" (withou the "") on the launch parameters and haven't seen them again, hope it fixed it and not just a coincidence. 
- Changed the resolution to 1280x800 (too fill up the screen) manually since the game started with a lower one and didn't changed automaticaly.
- Players that played Season One can load the save to keep their previous choices, the problem is that doesn't work on the Deck/Linux. If you don't have any other computer, there's a linux tutorial somewhere to help you with at (don't remember where, but probably you can easily find it on google). Easier way, get your hands on a win computer (or VM on a Mac since the newer Macs won't run these 32bit games), then open Season One (so it fetches the save from Steam Cloud), exit, and then opened Season Two, made it look for the Season One save, let the game start and exit. It will load the save to Steam Cloud and then you can continue on the Deck.

131168717.review:
Great sequel but not as legendary as the first.

I really enjoyed the second game in The Walking Dead series from Telltale. It tells yet another great story, lets you bond with the characters and is overall a work of art. I still think the first game was better in terms of story, but that did not change the fact that I enjoyed this one immensely. 

The Walking Dead: Season Two is the direct sequel to the first The Walking Dead game. It picks up where the first game ended and continues with Clementine as the main protagonist.

The story is a piece of perfection and, just like the first The Walking Dead review, I will not spoil anything. This is something that you need to experience for yourself.

One of the best aspects of this game is that it can import your choices and outcomes from the first game, including the 400 Days DLC. People react to you based on the choices you made from the original The Walking Dead. So epic. 
Graphicly, The Walking Dead: Season Two received a nice upgrade. Besides the improved cell shading and animations, the game is a lot darker, something that enhanced the experience really well. The sky is dusk yellow most of the time, giving you the feeling of an apocalypse wasteland.

The sound design is just as good as the first game, especially the voice acting of all the characters. It is the sound where Telltale games shines the most. This shows with the soundtrack, which is excellent. It even got nominated for several rewards. You know that you are doing it right when you achieve that level. 

The Walking Dead: Season Two plays in the same style as the original game in which you use point and click mechanics, quick time events and choice making to work to the ultimate ending of the game. Every choice has consequences, and, at times, real moral dilemmas are present in which both options are technically wrong or unfair, but you have to make a choice. 

You need to react fast at times and are not always giving the opportunity to think things through. This aspect of quick reaction is realistic and if you make a mistake in game by providing a wrong answer or an answer that people are not happy about, it is just like real life, in which you do not have the perfect response or solution available right away.

Originally, just like The Wolf Among Us, new episodes would come out every few months between each other. But, just like The Wolf Among Us, you can also buy the retail version, including all the episodes. 

The episodes themselves are great, every one of them and the overall length of the game and the episodes themselves is fair. You got a solid seventeen hours of story ahead of you when playing the game, which is very acceptable for just a story based, on rail point and click game.

Like I said, I would prefer the first game over this one, but this is my personal taste. I think this is mainly because of my attachment to Lee from the first game. 

Overall, I loved The Walking Dead: Season Two and, once again, Telltale Games earned my deepest respect for creating this beautiful game. 

Absolutely recommend it.

130885294.review:
The Walking Dead Season Two

Lo mejor del juego
La trama y el guión, ingeniosos y atrapantes. La historia engancha y poco a poco acabamos preocupándonos de los personajes, tal y como ocurre en cualquier serie de televisión de calidad.
El apartado artístico, que ha mejorado respecto a su predecesor. Los personajes, a pesar del estilo “dibujado” del juego, son capaces de transmitir una expresividad de la que carecen títulos con un apartado gráfico superior.
A diferencia de la primera temporada, nuestras decisiones tienen un peso mayor en el desenlace. Hay distintos finales que podemos conseguir en función de cómo actuemos.

Puntos negativos a mi parecer que le faltaron pulir un poco mas

El escaso nivel de dificultad. Los combates no son desafiantes, y la cantidad de puzles es muy inferior a la de la primera temporada. Parece que lo único que tenemos que hacer durante todo el juego es recoger objetos e interactuar con el entorno.
El sistema de toma de decisiones y las intervenciones en los diálogos importantes son menos creíbles a través de una niña pequeña.

En conclusión el juego es para que te sientes y lo veas, pudiendo llevar el ritmo y decidir elecciones que pueden cambiar muchas cosas. No cambia mucho del primero, pero tampoco hay que reprochárselo, porque si lo que buscas es una buena historia y una buena secuela este es tu juego.

Mi Puntuación Es De: 9/10

○○○○ Historia: 9/10 ○○○○
○○○○ Gráficos: 9/10 ○○○○
○○○○ Jugabilidad: 9/10 ○○○○
○○○○ Personajes: 10/10 ○○○○
○○○○ Ambientación: 9/10 ○○○○

129378977.review:
This is an [b] almost [/b] perfect sequel. It allows you to take control of Clementine, the girl you took care of in the first game and decide what type of person she will become. 

The games biggest weakness and strength is one character is [spoiler] Kenny, this is because his story wrapped up perfectly in the first game (if you saved Ben), it even concludes with his death. But now he's back and his anger is a lot worse. He is the main conflict of the game, whether you side with him or not, and that can be difficult when sometimes he's mad at you no matter what choice you make. [/spoiler]

There was a interesting idea with having a couple characters have two possible deaths, depending on your choices. But the idea falls flat. [spoiler] Nick can be killed by Walter which is interesting and makes narrative sense, due to his prior actions, or he can die off-screen and be found as a zombie, which is so disappointing. The second character I know of with this mechanic is Sarah, who can be killed after being too afraid to do something. Bringing the arc of her being Clem could've been without Lee to a close. Showing us that people need to be strong to survive now. Or she can fall off a balcony and get eaten because there's nothing you can do, and you get no chance of saving her yourself. It really sucks, but I think it would've been better off leaving that mechanic out if they weren't willing to actually change the story. [/spoiler]

This game is one hell of an adventure. If you are reading this I assume you've completed the first season and you understand that this game is a continuation of the first game.
 Being honest, the very first time I was introduced to the game was through YouTube, so playing this game I already knew all the outcomes and possibilities. Even if they were forgotten I would remember everything along the way, but my point is that even though I knew [u] EVERITHING [/u] about this game, it still made me directly enter the course of action, be a part of what's happening, to the point where I cried during the ending. And I want to place much emphasis on that because crying was a very big and personal problem with me. I have not cried for 5 years up to that point and I have tried to cry more than 30 times during this time period I believe because I thought that crying refreshes you, really makes you free of all the shit you keep inside of you. And this game made me cry. I'll be damned if I ever say anything bad about this masterpiece of a story. [spoiler] Cuz man.. when Kenny was telling Clementine to stay at Wellington.. I felt like he was telling that to me, I felt like I was the one who knew this guy since "the beginning". I was so extremely sad to say goodbye. The scene itself was manufactured so well that I felt like I was a direct part of it. Incredible, just incredible. [/spoiler] 
I could go on telling you about how characters are really well made and the story arcs make you care, teach you to forget or to blame, to make a choice or to obstain, how the quality of animations skyrocketted in comparison to the first season but I wouldn't. Personal experience with the game is what makes you appreciate it and I know damn well that my personal experience was flawless.

126195234.review:
[b]My Playtime:[/b] 10.2h (100% achievement, finished the game)
[b]Grindy Achievement(s):[/b] No.
[b]Optional Achievement(s):[/b] No.
[b]Difficult Achievement(s):[/b] No.

[h1]Intro[/h1]
[b]The Walking Dead: Season Two[/b] is the second installment of [url=https://store.steampowered.com/bundle/13313/The_Walking_Dead__Ultimate_Steam_Bundle/]The Walking Dead[/url] series, continued a few years after [b][url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/207610/The_Walking_Dead/]The Walking Dead[/url][/b] ([url=https://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198132503739/recommended/207610]my review[/url]) ends. It tells the story from Clementine's point of view who tries to survive the upcoming winter with a new group.

[b]Pros:[/b]
- Story branchings that lead to different endings
- You can transfer your decisions from the first game

[b]Cons:[/b]
- No manual save option

[b]Specs[/b]
Intel Core i5-9300H 2.40GHz, 8GB RAM, NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1650

[h1]Should you buy this game?[/h1]
[b]Yes.[/b]
[i]If you liked the first game, buy this game.[/i]

[hr][/hr]
[h1]In-Depth Review[/h1]

[h3]Visuals[/h3]
The game still uses the same unique style as the first season. Characters look like 2D portraits with their black lines on their models, while the environments take a more realistic look. I also liked how the grasses and plants look so detailed. The fire doesn't seem to match the environment, though - they look like lights more than anything.

[h3]Story[/h3]
The story tells a few years after the events in the first season. Clementine has learned more about how to survive in the apocalypse and become more mature with time. This makes her character looks cold most of the time - her eyes are squinted instead of wide when this happens to make it more apparent. Although she has to mature quicker than her age, she still can be gentle depending on the decision that you chose.

Choice matters for the story. Some dialogues only differ in the first few responses after your choice, but others will slightly impact the story sometime in the future. The most major changes will be the characters' deaths, which just like the first season, mostly won't matter since the character that won't die in one choice will either be gone or dead later on. I still think that's understandable since it can be hard to make a sequel with a lot of branching paths.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=971751160

The main topic of this season is trust. You'll be presented with a new group that you will get along with, but unlike the first season, it can be hard to trust people at this time - years have passed after the apocalypse starts. People already flocked around to make groups and they have information that you don't. You'll be left in the dark for some time and have to choose without knowing everything. This also put your loyalty to the test. With a group being as secretive as it is, can you trust them? Or should you ditch them and choose the other side? The pattern will keep on happening until you have to choose between people.

Being in an apocalypse for years, you might think that people are capable. The new people that she met were mostly useless; they might be able to fend themselves from the zombies, but they are not in the right mind. Most of the cast are mentally unstable, and they keep on arguing most of the time. Moreover, when push comes to shove, they will mostly have no choice but to rely on Clem, which has to do either emotional support or heavy lifting for the group.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2714764904

Still, some emotions are going through the game. It's not as impactful as how it was in the first season, but I don't mind since the pacing was faster this season. You will understand the tension and why people are feeling that way: the despair, the anger, the desperation - all of it can be felt from each of the characters. Sometimes, I even can't choose between the choices since I couldn't find a better way out of it.

As for the ending, it might not be as emotional and touching as the first one, but it was made brief. You get a scene, and bam - the game suddenly ends. There is no time for you to get closure or anything, which might be done in purpose for the sequel. Still, I enjoyed the story. I had to stop and think for a while about whether I made the right choice at that time. It felt like I was drawn to the tension in the story. The sudden decision at the intense moment near the end might have contributed to that, and I liked it for what it is.

[h3]The Game[/h3]
[b]The Walking Dead: Season Two[/b] doesn't have much in the gameplay department. Sometimes, the game will let you walk around, interact with objects, and talk to people, but they are mostly brief.

Most of the gameplay comes in the QTE section. They are usually the same ones like mashing the Q button or pressing an arrow button, although there are more complicated ones too. Still, you can retry them if you fail and they are easy enough to finish as long as you're paying attention and/or remembering which button to press.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=204876213

[b]Length and Replayability[/b]
I finished the game in 10.2h. The game was split into 5 chapters, meaning that each chapter lasts for ~2h. People can replay the game to have a different ending. However, since most choices at the beginning won't have much impact on the ending, I don't think replaying the game is a good idea, especially since you can't skip the cutscenes.

If you have played the first game (which you should), you can import your save to this game. Your decision will carry over to the rest of the game, although as I said before, they won't matter much. You also can have the game generate the choices if you don't have your save anymore.

[b]Issues[/b]
There is no manual save option. The game might tell when it does the saving, but sometimes the checkpoints can be far from each other. Moreover, there are no skip cutscene options. It can take time to replay the game to see the different endings this way.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
[b]The Walking Dead: Season Two[/b] might be less impactful than the first season, but it's still an enjoyable game. The gameplay is mostly the same with a focus on the story. I was hooked on it from the start until the end, and sometimes, my head even hurt thinking from all of the arguments. There are a lot of heated discussions going on, and people are at their limits. It's nice to see a different side of the apocalypse with the arguing and bashing, and if you already played and enjoyed the first game, I don't see a reason to not play this one, unless you are already stressed out and don't want to see people arguing when playing a game.

Dentro de todo, es una secuela decente, con cosas que la gente odia pero puedo entender que estén ahí, como Sarah, que al igual que Ben, refleja que antes que gente como Lee o Clementine, te vas a encontrar con gente guiada por el miedo que por otra cosa.

123027204.review:
Though not as emotionally satisfying as the original release, Season Two fittingly follows the original's events without skipping a beat and honestly feels accurate to what would happen in the wake of where we left our characters last time.  Clementine has gone from cute, innocent girl to protect into a much more somber old-for-her-age eleven year-old (which is bittersweet, no matter how you slice it).  Ultimately, as this game gets further along, you realize it is addressing the abuse cycle and how people act when they are stuck in it and IF they try to break free.  You get a real sense of how broken the apocalypse would make some people.

Major changes from the first game are the lack of commentary from the player character whenever they look at objects (minor you'd think, but it really adds a sense of melancholy mood throughout the game).  Choices seem a lot more punishing and tend to lead to bad outcomes no matter how you slice them.  Tons of "what traumatic situation can we force this little girl into next" vibes in order to beat the player with how harsh and sad this world is for our main character to experience.  Overall, the gameplay is generally identical to the first one with a minor new mechanic or two that are well-explained.

The most glaring issue I'd say with making Clementine the main protagonist this time around is the fact that yes, she is still just an eleven year-old child.  Unlike Lee in the first game, when you make choices and speak up quite constantly (obviously as the player character)....people wouldn't listen to you all the time.  Adults make calls (especially in life-or-death survival), not children.  So that tends to break immersion if you really think about how Clem's choices would truly affect the groups she finds herself in.  This is simply an unfortunate consequence of the setup.

Some emotionally satisfying moments and some very warm callbacks to the first season help this round as you struggle along in survival.  Lots of characters get picked off and force the player to wonder if they should emotionally detach from everyone like some of the characters you meet have already done to ensure their survival.

All in all, not as fresh and memorable as Season 1 will remain to be, but a competent sequel if you are captured by the story narrative of Clementine as it continues to play out.  Onto Season 3.

Little things:
-No sixth DLC episode this time around.
-All achievements unlock by simply playing through to the end.
-If there was "one" useless character in the first season (we know who I'm talking about) who just drags the group down....well, this one has like, two.  (You really want to get rid of them despite what the game tells you to do.)

122456666.review:
This season was a good one just like the previous.

The story was was good, gameplay still pretty much the same, with decent visual improvements

The story this time around was also good, and it had a difference of being more constantly on the move and in danger, unlike the first season's more down time, and slow spots in its story. 
The characters, while not as memorable as the first season, were well developed and like-able.

The gameplay was pretty much very similar, though one thing i noticed is that in this game you wont have as much open areas to walk around in and interact with certain stuff, and talk to the characters in it as much as that feature was present in the first game. That was disappointing as i liked these open areas. This game still had some of these open areas, but they were usually more linear, not much to talk about with the characters there, less interact-ables, and generally you went through them quicker. That could have been for the games more on the move style, where we were always on the move unlike the first game, and that added generally more action to the game, in turn adding more quick time events, which were quite improved on, adding more controls to use, and were much more natural and dynamic. 
Other minor gameplay elements were added too, especially during action scenes, like the added amount of times you actually shoot weapons, with proper aiming this time, and the new click and hold to a direction feature.

The visuals, preserving the first game's comic book style, were very well improved on. 
I criticized the first game for having inconsistencies in terms of some really nice looking scenes with sharp textures, but some areas with blurry low res textures. In this game this was almost completely fixed with sharp textures all across the game. The farther backdrops were improved too, being more layered, instead of just being a 2D wall like the first game. The lighting seen some good changes too. 
This game was just generally much more visually polished and consistent which was very appreciated.

This game, while not expanding on my most fun aspect of exploring small open areas every now and then, was still a great game with a phenomenal story, relatively good enough gameplay, and improved visuals.

I do recommend this game, mostly for its story at the very least.

122321945.review:
Disclaimer: I've owned season two but eventually played it via the Definitive Collection on Epic. There's no real difference so I saw fit to put here my thoughts about season 2.
Disclaimer#2: I have enjoyed most of my time playing this. I'm not exactly saying that I "don't recommend" this. Why thumbs down then? Well, all in all I find myself feeling very disappointed. Since this game has a very good reception I'm allowing myself to rant about it more than usual.
Disclaimer#3: Spoilers may follow

[h1]Short review[/h1]
+ All iconic Telltale games features are here - cool soundtrack, minimalistic but good comic-book style graphics, cinematic experience, story-driven adventure.
+ Story has some very effective and intense moments.
+ That's really tiny, but the GUI is so much better and more responsive than that of the previous game. Sheesh!

-Still, weaker story than of season 1.
-Characters usually lack depth and true interest, and are at best forgettable to downright annoying.
-[spoiler] I expected more continuity from season 1 and something more than just killing (almost) everyone and starting a new saga with completely different groups of people which would die sooner or later too, etc. [/spoiler]
-Choices have so little effect.
-Horrible technical bug which would not allow to save in the middle of an episode since ep.3 and onwards(may be random, but still).

Longer review follows.

[h1]Technicalities[/h1]
Let's put aside the technical matters first - In this aspect, season 2 is mostly superior or just the same as season 1: This is a quality adventure with a cinematic gameplay. It's fully story driven. The soundtrack is good and fitting very well the atmosphere for both the intense and calmer moments of the story. The graphics are slightly improved, but the usual Telltale comic-book style. The in-game interface is tidied up a bit. Also, playing this straight after season 1, I've noticed how the menus there were very laggy and clunky and here they were (finally) much more smoother and responsive. Which is pretty important imo.

One horrible thing in this aspect is that the checkpoints system seem to randomly break at some point. Since EP3 and onwards I could not save in the middle of an episode. I have tried messing with it several times and had to restart the episode about 3 times after completing a relatively big part of the episode. Since they won't ever let us skip dialogues, this was very painful.
Also, as someone who likes to play in a short intervals, it was rather painful to have to play whole episodes in a ~2-3 hours sessions.
After googling this a bit, seems that this bug affects the original game as well, and not only the definitive edition. Also looks like it does not affect EVERYONE but would randomly occur to some players. Still, no solution to this and that's very disappointing.

[h1]Story since Season 1[/h1]
Now, I can go on to what really matters in this kind of games - the story elements.
As I mentioned at first, I DID enjoy this game very much, most of the time.
The story was intense and intriguing. Clementine is a very likable and relatable protagonist.
Still, I'm majorly disappointed at many points of it and can't help but feel this goes a few steps down from season 1.

Not entirely sure why, but the writers chose to completely ditch almost everyone and everything that's happened in season 1. [spoiler]Of the very few characters that survived, they pretty much finish off Omid and Christa right at the beginning of the season. The part of Clementine having to survive all alone in the world for some time was a strong point of the story, but quickly enough she connects to a new group of people, just to be entangled at some dramas which feel awkwardly parallel to those of S1.
Anyway, having Kenny back was a nice surprise (I never liked him, though) and the very tiny cameo appearances of the 400 Days characters felt more like an insult.
And right, there's Bonnie, which was OK but didn't really fit into any major part of the story in both season 1 and 2, imo.
At the end of this season, once again most of the characters are dead [/spoiler] and so it appears that although making this a "Series", the writers didn't really want anything to do with any story too complex and continuous but rather more self-contained stories with disposable characters.

[h1]Characters[/h1]
Which leads me to the next point - characters were much weaker in this season. While in season 1 we have at least had the time to get to know and connect to the characters, learn a bit about their origins and motives, and maybe even slightly care about them, in here there was very little time left for that. I guess a zombie apocalypse really is not the best time to get to know one another, but still, the result is that this season - to me - felt more like a thriller with chains of intense events where I really just wanted Clementine to survive while she entangled with a group of strangers tearing itself apart. The whole writing and dynamic between the characters just felt a little off to me, and it seemed like large portions of the game were about watching some stranger adults fight and yell at each other with someone dying every now and then one way or the other.

[h1]Choices[/h1]
What leads me once again to the next point - Telltale games have always claimed to tailor themselves to how we play. At this point, I've already played TWD S1, Batman, The Wolf Among Us, and some Game of Thrones, and I understand that this is mostly an illusion. STILL - in those titles it felt like there's at least SOME variety possible by our choices. In season 2 - it is very apparent that the choices matter even less than before, making the tiniest and not very interesting alterations to the heavily pre-scripted scenes of the game.

[h1]Ending[/h1]
With all that's said above, I was still relatively alright with Season 2 until I played Episode 5 to the end. While there was still the right amount of heart warming along with intense and\or heart-breaking moments, this episode really brought to story to fall flat on its face. [spoiler]I've really felt nothing much happened besides what's left of the group just fighting with each other. The whole saga with the russians&Arwo felt completely forced and redundant. Towards the end, of course we go on with killing some more characters or just having them ditching off so that the story won't have to actually deal with them (not the Mike & Bonnie felt like very significant characters to the whole picture). [/spoiler]
The very ending may actually alter significantly depending on your very final choices. Many of the possible endings (around 5 or 6 in total, I think) are very well done and emotionally draining scenes, fitting to this season.
Still, for me, the final episode was mostly a mess, and while I haven't played seasons 3 & 4 yet and holding myself to not look up for spoilers, I already assume that it doesn't really matter what ending I came to eventually, this will have very little to no effect on the rest of the series.

120229529.review:
So I played the first two chapters at the point of this review, and I am quite disappointed. I played the first Season exactly 9 years ago, and I still have a better impression of the first season than the second season up until now. 

What is good: the characters are more or less believable, the athmosphere is really good (read: depressing, as it should be) and I was happy to see Clementine again, which I kinda developed fatherly feelings for in season one. Which tells you how good the storytelling in S1 was. 

What is bad/annoying: S1 was basically an interactive movie where you chose minor plot changes (but with much emotional baggage) like which side-character dies or which way to go, or who to cheer up. S2 makes you feel very openly that your choices don't matter. I know the general direction of the plot is fixed, but there are several deaths in this game that feel really impactful at first, but then you notice that those characters where hardcoded to die. I had a saving-error and had to redo a part of the game, so I chose a different plot option. The result was 100% the same. Down to the t. The worst part is that the game does not do a very good job at hiding this fact. 
There are "sneaking sections" where my only "choice" is to click to go into the direction that I have to go...

The story itself seems alright until now, so I will continue "playing" it. Mostly because I am invested in Clementine from Season 1 still. But it really really feels like an interactive movie. Which is annoying.
More so: after each episode, there is an outlook what will happen in the next episode, and you cannot skip it. If you minimize the window, the game will wait for you to maximize again, so you must watch it!  So they basically spoiler the plot for the next episode.  Each episode is about 1,5h to play, so when you have a more extended gaming evening, you are *forced* to sit through plot-spoilers for the thing you plan to do in the next hour. 

So all in all, I will vote negative to express my dissatisfaction with some of the story-telling choices they did, even though the story itself is indeed interesting. Do with that info what you want.

119767071.review:
Lo compré porque ya lo había jugado hace muchos años y recuerdo haberlo disfrutado bastante... ahora que lo volví a jugar puedo decir que no me parece un mal juego, pero la historia me parece bastante mediocre por momentos (sin mencionar lo mucho que se pasaron por las pelotas mis decisiones)
 
[spoiler]-La escena con Sam me parece muy gratuita. Todo esto de la mordida y encerrarte en el cobertizo pierde sentido a los 15 minutos.
-¿No se les ocurrió algo mejor para Christa? Ya pasaron como 8 años, 3 temporadas y todavía no son capaces ni de darle un cierre a su historia ._. hacerla desaparecer de la nada, sin explicación alguna de su paradero y sin si quiera decirnos si sigue viva o no me parece muy perezoso, 
-A diferencia del primer juego, en cuanto un personaje pasa a ser determinante, automáticamente pierde cualquier tipo de relevancia en la historia :/ ¿para que me voy a molestar en salvar a Sarah o Pete si mueren a las pocas horas? ¿Para que voy a salvar a Alvin o a Nick si literalmente dejan de existir por el resto del juego?
-400 Days termina convirtiéndose en una perdida de guita y de tiempo. Sus personajes tienen con suerte una o dos apariciones, y Bonnie (la menos interesante y más odiosa de los 6) ni siquiera tiene un status claro a menos de que la cagues caminando sobre el hielo. Literalmente lo único que hacen en todo el juego es cagar a tiros a Carlos y a Nick ._. osea NADA. En lugar de poner a ese grupo de rusos (que estaban más desubicados que chupete en el orto) podrían haberlos puesto a ellos en esa escena... tendría más sentido.
-El regreso de Kenny arruina completamente todo su desarrollo en la primer temporada. Hacen que su sacrificio no tenga sentido y es más que obvio que se lo sacaron del orto, porque literalmente no había forma de que sobreviva. [/spoiler]

Como dije, el juego no es malo pero siento que agarraron todo lo que hacía genial al primero juego y se lo pasaron por el centro del orto. Se siente muy vacío, es complicadisimo poder encariñarse con personajes que no van a durar ni 5 minutos, tus decisiones no tienen ningún tipo de peso en la historia y solo cambian pequeños detalles (sin contar el final)...
Si no te interesa mucho la historia de Clementine entonces no te lo recomiendo, porque literalmente es el único personaje que vale la pena.

played season one on my brother's xbox 360 after looking through a couple of the games he barely touched. literally fell in love. im maybe halfway through ep2 of this season (which i bought after maybe a couple days after finishing season one) and its literally amazing. im so glad this seems to be series that wasn't just good for the first season. im loving clem's character development. this entire thing is just chef's kiss. maybe my favorite video game series. it's so freaking real, none of that plan B, fake stakes crap. probably going to put money into every season. i can tell ill be devastated when it's over. crazy dude.

edit: just finished it. I... am fragile. It's a good thing I took a few months break before starting the last episode, I think if I still carried all the emotions from the earlier episodes, I would've DEFINITELY CRIED. the thing about this series is that it's just so focused on creating a good story, which i can vouch it does, that the tear-jerking moments work so well because it doesn't feel like a cheap grab for emotions. i know you know what I mean when i say that, because so many story games will set up things just for the big cry moment. this season - there was no huge "we really want you to cry right now" moment in particular. it just got worse, became status quo, got worse, became status quo. it felt like emotional survival in the circumstances of clem's actual survival. the characters are so real. oh god if you see this just play the series.

FAVORITE GAME SERIES EVER.

117910789.review:
The Walking Dead Season 2 is a worthy continuation of the story which begun with Season 1.

I consider the first season of this game series to be fantastic and this one simply continues that trend. The quality of the writing is still at the kind of level that the first one set and the voice acting and other aspects too. The quality of the models/textures at times can be a little better than the first.

For the most part this game plays like the previous one. You control a character from a third person perspective and essentially live out a portion of their story during this zombie apocalypse. At certain times you're given some hard choices and they will change the outcomes and details of some aspects of the story. There were some improvements with some of the Quick Time Events (QTE) scenarios and some of the "mini-game" sections compared to the previous titles.

The technical gripes I had with the first season were addressed for this sequel. No more occasional stuttering/frame rate drops in specific scenes.

Overall I would reccomend this title if you like games with a focus on story.

[b]Description:[/b]  
TWD: Season 2 is an adventure game where the story is the main reason for playing it. The interactive parts/puzzles aren’t very challenging so you can enjoy the story more easily and avoid getting stuff very often. It continues the story of the main character. 

[b]Achievements:[/b]  
[b]How many:[/b] 40 Achievements, all story related. 
[b]How much time:[/b] It took me around 10 hours.
[b]Game difficulty:[/b] Very Easy. 
[b]Achievement’s difficulty:[/b]  Very easy, you just need to finish the game.

[b]Overall opinion:[/b]  
I recommend this game if you’re into The Walking Dead shows or interactive books in general. It continues the story of the main character from the first game. The overwhelming positive reviews don’t lie.

115517580.review:
[h1] A continuously straightforward story of survival horror[/h1]

Let me start by saying that it's good but not wonderful. Unlike the first one, I felt absolutely no challenge, just annoyed to restart some parts when you fail the QTE.
There are no puzzles nor complicate item combinations like in classic point & click games. 
The only thing to do is walk around, click on things, succeed at QTE and make some choices (with a few that are quite gut-wrenching).

The story is not as good as the first one, the locations and situations are interesting. The plot has its up and low and is good enough but I was let down by the ever expendable cast and abrupt endings. It seems it's always "X joins the group" "X becomes your best friend" "X dies horribly", "Y joins the group", etc. 
Other than that, it will provide you the Walking Dead feeling.

In conclusion, I would recommend it only if you are a huge Walking Dead fan and would tell others to skip it if you wanted a complex and intriguing story with devilish puzzles. If you can get it cheap and on sale, then it might be worth it.

115137270.review:
If Season 1 was a story about a good man seeking redemption for doing a bad thing, Season 2 is about a girl growing into a woman such a brutal, visceral way you can't help but believe it. 

While it didn't quite reach the highs of Season 1, this game did just as masterful a job of tearing at my heartstrings. There is something so poetic and indescribable about how Clementine is simultaneously becoming her own person while every so often, you see Lee in her. Lee and Clementine are two of the best video game characters ever, full stop. The ending of this was inevitable; it was built up over and over and I think it was executed flawlessly. 

I have some issues with the narrative decisions during the epilogue, but the last major deicison on the playground was perfect. Although I immediately knew what I had to do, I couldn't make my thumb physically hit the button. I hated it but I pushed through it, and felt sweeping relief and sadness. Clem's flashback reminded me how damn good the first game is, as well, and I dropped a good few tears on the way. I think the supporting characters may have actually been more interesting than in Season 1, but here and there parts of the script felt shaky with them adding and losing new characters so frequently. Still though, you MUST play this if you played Season 1.

114453605.review: One of the best games I ever played. I didn't know about this series or Telltale, I got the first game for free from humblebundle (I previously watched only the series from AMC) in like 2017 and since then I got the entire series.

114406963.review:
[h1]English[/h1]

As in the first season, Telltale put a board here.

This game is simply a masterpiece in every way.
The story is once again awesome, because it can hit you very emotionally, especially when it comes to the death of old friends. [spoiler] Kenny’s death was predictable, but it hit me the most. [/spoiler]
The decisions you have to make now are harder than ever, as in most cases you have to choose between the group and [spoiler]Kenny[/spoiler], to whom you have a very strong bond.
I also like the new faces that have been added, as they all have a unique character that never existed before. Only one or the other comes a little too short and you could have gotten more out of them.
The soundtrack is once again very coherent and underlines the events perfectly and invites you to listen in on the side.

I can only praise the game and I make a crystal clear recommendation to buy!

[h1]Deutsch[/h1]

Wie auch bei der ersten Season hat Telltale hier ein Brett hingelegt.

Dieses Spiel ist einfach in jeder Hinsicht ein Meisterwerk. 
Die Story ist mal wieder der Hammer, da sie einen sehr emotional treffen kann, vor allem wenn es zum Tod von alt bekannten Freunden kommt. [spoiler]Der Tod von Kenny war eigentlich vorherzusehen, doch traf er mich von allen am meisten.[/spoiler] 
Die Entscheidungen, die man jetzt treffen muss, sind so schwer wie noch nie, da man sich in den meisten Fällen zwischen der Gruppe und [spoiler]Kenny[/spoiler] entscheiden muss, zu denen man jeweils eine sehr große Bindung aufgebaut hat. 
Auch gefallen mir die neuen Gesichter die hinzugekommen sind, da sie alle einen einzigartigen Charakter haben, den es zuvor noch nicht gab. Nur kommt mir der ein oder andere ein wenig zu kurz und man hätte aus diesen mehr herausholen können.
Der Soundtrack ist mal wieder sehr stimmig und unterstreicht die Geschehnisse perfekt und lädt auch zum nebenbei reinhören ein.

Ich kann das Spiel nur loben und ich spreche eine glas klare Kaufempfehlung aus!

At first, I thought it was kinda boring and not as good as the first season.
But from Episode 2 onward, this game became a non-stop tension rollercoaster.

Just like the first game, it has many nerve-wracking moments and choices.
This game also loves to troll you with its choices, as they are either brilliantly set to make you unexpectedly choose the wrong people to support, or the set of events to flow with. it also has multiple endings that don't fail to make you full of sadness and regret

If you liked the first game, you definitely want to play this too.
The only issues with this game are that some characters aren't well-written, some go quickly and there are a lot of "illusion of choice" moments but I guess it's kind of the charm.

9/10

108897672.review:
[h1]The Walking Dead Season Two-En medio de 2 bandos:[/h1] 

[h1]Contexto:[/h1] 

Es la segunda temporada y continuación del videojuego exitoso The Walking Dead, seguimos tomando decisiones para avanzar pero esta vez la protagonista es Clementine.

[h1]Historia:[/h1] 

Tras los sucesos de la primera temporada podemos ver a una Clementine diferente, poco a poco haciéndose más valiente junto a las enseñanzas de Lee, a medida que avanzamos podemos encontrarnos con rostros conocidos y así mismo nuevos. Lo mas inquietante y lo que a muchos nos puede dar miedo es tener que elegir entre dos grupos de personas a las que uno va agarrándoles cariño, esta entrega esta cargada de muchas emociones haciéndonos sentir muchas veces culpables o con satisfacción de poder ayudar, de principio a fin, hay que saber elegir sabiamente.

[h1]Destacado:[/h1] 

La mejora de en la movilidad del personaje, así como escenarios más grandes, se amplía la interacción que podemos tener con los personajes, hay bastantes que sin duda afectara de una forma mas puntal en la historia, en algunos momentos te dan ganas de repetir el capitulo por como termina dándote cuenta del montón de decisiones que puedes cambiar, así como la ambientación también juega un papel crucial.    
 
[h1]Puntos negativos:[/h1] 

El único punto negativo es que sigue siendo algo torpe al momento de caminar o seleccionar alguna opción, aun así es fácil de adaptarse y no arruina la experiencia de juego.

[h1]Para Resumir:[/h1] 

Sigue siendo una obra maestra y ahora que estamos viviendo la experiencia desde el controlar a Clementine, sin duda ha mejorado en varias cosas sin dejar de ser autentico, aparte de conocer un poco más a nuestra gran protagonista.

[b]Mi Puntuación Es De: 9.5/10[/b] 

Historia: 9/10
Gráficos: 9/10
Jugabilidad: 9/10
Personajes: 10/10
Ambientación: 9/10

[h1]!!Gracias por tomarse el tiempo de leer, un abrazo!![/h1]
