108218557.review:
Comparing this season 2 to season 1, I still like the story and the characters, Clementine above all. She is really well written and interesting.

But i have some troubles which are the reason i give this a negative review:
- no official french translation, which is bad since s1 and 3 have it.
- there is a general "choose X then it doesn't really matter because the story will consider you will have chosen Y or something close to Y in any case" issue which is really problematic because it happens in times where you would have a different "reasoning" for story in the season 1. So the comparison to s1 is not for the better on this point. 
- At some point, you even have the NPC prevent you to do your choice. If that was all, I would just shrug and think about something else. But it is then marked in the choices as "You choose not to do it"... and that pissed me a lot because i didn't know if it was a continuity bug or just the game preventing me to have my choice taken into account by the game and "forcing" the choice I didn't want at all.
- and finally, but that's maybe only me, there are multiple time where I couldn't play the Clementine I wanted. I wanted my Clementine to be a hard human, transformed to steel due to what she lived with Lee in s1. There were many times I wanted to be able to say sentences as "I will kill you" to some characters in the game or even think those sentences. But I couldn't. And even when there is the opportunity for revenge, I only have the choice to watch it, not to enact it myself or at least try to do it myself. 
- Finally the story of the game uses more of "stupid" moments. At some points I was like: "ok i get it, you don't like each other. Can you just shut up and deal with the walking deads who are coming on us first, then resume yelling at each other?" The ending of episode 4 is just such bad moment. I didn't felt anything for the scene because I was just mad that the characters in the game were stupid to the point where their survival is of no matter to me.
- in episode 2 i would have loved to make a shot myself because the character in game is so stupid that he thinks his bullets go through concrete or sturdy walls... I understand the fact that Clementine is a little girl so i cannot shoot okay, but then at least give me an option to TELL the character that what he intends to do is stupid...
- for a game with few bullets, the characters sure waste them a lot.
- And finally the story offers more and more ingame reasons to just give up on some characters, and go with another character... but no, you are forced to go with the stupid ones even if the going away one makes more sense. That's a bit sad because it goes with the other "story forces me" issues of this season.
In the first season, staying with the group made sense, and leaving didn't so it was totally okay and not a problem. [spoiler]Here the conflcits come from a rotten group at its core and... you will not be able to leave when you want even if it makes sense to leave with the "smart" character.[/spoiler]

- the episode 4 ends with characters saying something ([spoiler]i stole the meds from the Russian Arvo guy [/spoiler] ) which is simply not true: i choose not to do that thing. It is never explained if it is a continuity error, a deliberate lie from the characters, or something else. It feels really bad because I would have loved to say "it was a lie." [spoiler]the whole episode 5 is based on a lie in my playthrough since i didn't steal the meds from Arvo in episode 4, and at NO point can i say it in game. It was itching me from the start of episode 5 and reduced the impact of all which followed.[/spoiler]
All in all, it is still a good and compelling story but it could have been a lot better.

However, if you play those games, i think you play for the whole plot, and as such, season 2 is mandatory to understand what Clementine goes through after that season 1 described where she comes from. So take my "negative" review, as a critics against the game series philosophy on choices and consequences in this season, not the story, nor the whole series.

106817589.review:
This game is the 2nd best story out of Telltale's walking dead franchise. They came very close to the perfection of the orignal. Lots of emotional highs and lows.

My only 2 complaints:

1. As usual your choices don't actually matter. It's just the illusion of choice. It's what you expect from a Telltale title. It can be overlooked though since the story itself is intriguing. It would be nice though if your choices actually had a lasting impact instead of always ending up at the same crossroad no matter what you choose. I understand, however that can be difficult and/or expensive to program multiple branching paths like that.

2. The adults in this game are mostly useless. So often they rely on Clementime, (who if im not mistaken is a 10 year old girl at this time in the series) to vitally important tasks for them. Or to make very important decisions for the group. Like I get this is the apocalypse and kids grow up fast and probably have a larger say in what happens in a survival group like this. But the only person who would have this much reason to put so much faith in Clementine is Kenny since they have history. There's just a bit too much of the grown men and women standing around with their thumbs in their pockets for me to overlook it.

It's still worth experiencing at least once though.

105018160.review:
Antes de ir con la reseña me gustaria mencionar dos cosas:

La primera es que los subtitulos del juego están en inglés, pero se puede poner en español de una forma muy sencilla gracias a las guias de la comunidad de Steam.
Lo segundo es que en esta reseña aré alusión al juego anterior a este The Walking Dead: Season Two, por lo que si no lo has jugado, puede aparecer algún spoiler.

Ahora si, vamos con la reseña!

The Walking Dead: Season Two, sigue la historia de Clementine, la niña que Lee (nuestro anterior protagonista) rescata al inicio del apocalipsis zombie. Al perder casi por completo a su grupo de compañeros de la primera entrega, Clementine deberá sobrevivir sola en un mundo donde la fina linea entre enemigo o aliado cada vez se difumina mas.

The Walking Dead: Season Two sigue su linea de la primera entrega, donde las decisiones que tomes tendrán consecuencias futuras en la historia. Jugablemente no sigue siendo la gran cosa, pero si que es verdad que se han añadido algunas combinaciones de botones para superar determinadas situaciones que en la anterior entrega no estaban. La historia es el punto fuerte de esta clase de juegos, pero en esta ocasión me ha parecido peor que la primera season, aunque sigue siendo bastante buena, y consigue engancharte lo suficiente como para siempre querer saber lo que pasa a continuación.

En definitiva, si te gustan las aventuras graficas episodicas, con tematica zombie y una trama bastante entretenida te recomiendo este juego, eso si, cuando lo veas de oferta.

I started playing this game right after I finished the first instalment and I believe it's the way how to enjoy this great series the most. 

I actually have nothing to add on top of what I already wrote about the first season. The way how these games are presented - in episodic dozes with good story structure - suits this genre perfectly. After all it is basically an interactive story so maybe, in a way, as a medium it's closer to a movie than a game. 
As a game though, there is nothing much really to talk about because it's just an exploration of presented environments with quick time events and dialogue choices. Pros:

Cons:

Nothing.

Go and grab it (along with the rest of the series).

102767507.review:
The Walking Dead: Season Two is a sequel to Telltale's Walking Dead game, taking place almost 2 years after the events of the first season. Gameplay is the same as many Telltale games, a story-focused game where you get to move around sometimes but most of the time you'll be choosing dialogue options, and sometimes QTEs. If you're expecting a combat game, you won't find it here.

This season we focus on Clementine instead of Lee, and we play as her throughout the whole game. You will meet groups of survivors, and like last season, you must prepare yourself for some feels since some of them will definitely die, and you can't help it. A strong point in this season for me is the appearance of Carver, a human antagonist voiced by Michael Madsen, whose voice I enjoy because of Dishonored and overall an interesting character.

You don't have to be a fan of The Walking Dead franchise or even zombie stories to enjoy this game. It doesn't really connect with the books or series. You just need to like story games, and you'll enjoy Telltale's TWD series. If you like one, buy all 4.

102367350.review:
The Walking Dead is brilliant, 11/10 type of game that is one of the most enjoyable story genre games in my long experience of playing these styles of games. Normally, I'm against [i]'movie style games' [/i] but The Walking Dead 2 does a great job of engaging the player with the story and leading them in the right direction while still giving them that sort of [i]'open world feel'[/i]. The only game that does this better that I can think of is [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/1222140/Detroit_Become_Human/]Detroit - Become Human[/url], however, both games shine in different ways. 

I'd also like to acknowledge how well this game plays with emotions and then leads you through the story, leaving that insatiable feeling in your gut. I mean, [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/261030/The_Walking_Dead_Season_Two/#app_reviews_hash]the game is literally bringing people to tears, because of how well it does this.[/url] Just to give you a taste of how emotional the dialogue is: 

[spoiler] Clementine: "I'm scared, Lee."
  Lee: [i]"What can I tell you to make it better?"[/i]
  Clementine: "That you won't leave me."
  Lee: "Oh, I wouldn't do that. I promise. Everything's gonna be all right."[/spoiler]


It's quite apparent when you compare both the reviews, and the improved gameplay and animation itself, that TellTale has learned from [url=https://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/game-of-thrones-a-telltale-games-series]their failures in the past [/url]and sought out to develop a game that has more or less defined the story genre itself. 

The series itself has its ups and downs but the [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/207610/The_Walking_Dead/]earlier Walking Dead games [/url]are incredible. If I'm being honest, there were very few times where I knew what was going to happen, [spoiler]or who might die[/spoiler] The game keeps you on your toes. It's not predictable in any way, shape or form and that is something that not many story games can do.

 My only criticism is that sometimes it feels too much like you're playing a detective game at times, as well as the fact that when you open the game it says [b]"The story is tailored to how you play"[/b] [spoiler]which is more or less a bit misleading, and as soon as you replay the game you will see that your choices have little to no impact on the story[/spoiler] That said, I still commend the developers for the amazing story that this game has to offer and I'm sad to have seen it die out over recent years but it was a masterpiece of its time and I enjoyed every second of it. I'm really sad to see the company shut down after such emotional yet brilliant masterpieces like these, however the series will live on,[i] providing people keep playing it.[/i]

101438320.review:
SPOILERS AHEAD!

In The Walking Dead Season Two you play as Clementine, after the events of the first season you're left with Christa and Omid. Sadly, Omid dies in a f*cking bathroom right at the beginning and you're left only with Christa to try and get to Wellington, a safe place she talks about. You two got attacked and got separated, then Clementine has to survive alone, but it doesn't go too well from the start, you get badly injured and then two men find and save you before taking you to their group.

The story is filled with a lot more action than season one, actually there's almost non-stop action, making you feel like nowhere is safe and so there's this constant pressure that anything could happen at any given time, and I like that, because it really is like that, you might start to like a character and next thing you know, there's a bullet in their head or they might die in a dumb way, but I think this is more realistic, since not everyone has a "heroic" death, sometimes they just die from dumb stuff.

There's also moments that get the best of you, for example, when you get captured by Carver, there's a scene when this guy slaps Clementine and OH MAN I wanted to punch that sonuvabitch through my monitor.

Most of the characters are unique and interesting, but some were questionable, Luke was likeable at the beginning and he seemed like a character you can trust, but then when you try to escape Carver's camp or whatever that was, he tries to stop you once again and when you finally had him at gunpoint you choose not to shoot him? Like after all he's done he thinks about letting him live? If you're gonna let him live he's gonna come after you, AGAIN, and this time to kill you, he chased you for like 5 nights or so  and you think he won't try again? And a lot of moments when he doesn't even think straight or just says senseless stuff, he once almost gets your group killed because instead of looking out for walkers and scouting the area he f*cks around with Jane, and since I mentioned Jane can I just say that she's actually mental? She comes out as a loner and even left the group but then she comes back, she does save us though I'll give her that, and after that you're glad she came back but you'll soon regret it, because near the end when Clem, Jane and Kenny get separated in the snowstorm and meet again she comes to you without AJ and tells you to stand back and watch so you'll see that Kenny is a bad man? B*tch.. you hid AJ and lied that he died just to get Kenny angry so he'll fight you? FOR WHAT? She actually deserved to die there, of course Kenny is gonna be angry, especially after how much he lost along the way, Duck, Katjaa, Sarita and now you come at him with that bullsh*t? Of course he lost his sh*t, he tought AJ died when he swore he'd look out for him.

But besides that, the story was amazing, the human interactions, the trauma surrounding each of the characters, the raw-ness of it all blended it together beautifully. The ending brought a tear in my eye to be honest, Kenny sacrificed himself so Clem and AJ could make it inside Wellington and have a chance at living as close as you can get to a normal life, he gives AJ his hat and then tells you [i]"I'm real glad to have met you, Clementine."[/i] that sh*t had me bawling, not gonna lie. :(

The Walking Dead Season Two is a perfect continuation of the first season and I'm glad I was here to experience it.

Absolutely beautiful.

100633100.review:
Continuation of the first story. This time the game focuses on the day-to-day survival and human contacts, without a clear goal. 

[i]Warning: for the story and characters, The Walking Dead: Season One should be played before this. There will be spoilers of S1 in this review. If you haven't played S1 and are interested in playing these, I recommend not reading this review beyond the header. You can find my review of S1 [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/TNTFTB/recommended/207610/]here[/url]. [/i] 

[h2]Alone, and trying to survive [/h2]
With Lee departed, Clementine has to survive on her own, something she isn't capable of yet. She has to find a group of people to stay alive, but the world has become hostile towards strangers. 
This game focuses even more on the human interactions during an apocalypse and staying alive during the winter. There is no clear goal like in S1 (finding parents, or a boat), just to survive and to get along with each other. 

[h2]Upgraded technicals [/h2]
S2 has upgraded significantly over S1 visualwise. The resolution is a lot higher, and there has been clear effort to make every scene as nice as could be. S1 created resources, which can be found in S2.
Music and voice acting are always good with Telltale games. 
And with Telltale games, QTE's are a staple. Sadly. 

[h2]My experience [/h2]
Some parts are better than S1, but overall the experience was a bit worse. That sounds more severe than the reality, S1 is a very good game. 
S2 is a lot more streamlined at least. S1 fell a bit silent at times, which doesn't happen in S2. There is a very good balance between action, dialogue and social interaction. There are a lot of locations, just like S1. This also means there is never a save home to stay, and thus there is never a sense of security for Clementine. 
And that is a very weak point in this game. A child like Clementine is relatable for many people, but in an apocalypse world?? Lee was such a strong protagonist, especially with Clementine. Alone she is vulnerable, although she is tough as nails. It just less fun to follow a child in a damned world. 
The game excells in character development and human interaction. It takes it time to converse between the different characters, and develope their relationship, for better or worse. This is very realistically done, as far as I can determine. 
I have come to accept that Telltale games have the illusion of choice. All choices do is adjust a few lines, or maybe the way someone dies. This doesn't mean I appreciate such shallow depth choices, but it is what it is. 

72/100

Although I didn't find this game as emotionally impactful as Season 1, it still managed to hit me in the feels at the end. This game did do a great job of having the player come along the journey of maturity and growth for Clementine. The newly introduced mechanics did little to the gameplay. except for the quick-time events that added some spice to the otherwise monotonous button mashing. The interface for the game is improved with the radial menu as opposed to the previous scroll one. Visually, the game is pretty similar to Season 1. I felt that the pacing for Season 2 felt awkard, as it seemed like the story hit a climax at Episode 2 and the final two episodes felt rushed. 

Nevertheless, the game is still good. Play it.

99424972.review:
One of the greatest and most heart-wrenching endings to a story-based game I've seen. After revisiting it years later, I found myself making the same choices still, and ended up with the same ending. It's never easy to see a good friend go, and it's even harder to hurt someone you love. I won't name names so to not spoil the ending for anyone that hasn't played, all I will say is that this was an incredible experience, and I only wish Telltale Games didn't shut down, I would have loved more of TWD, and even a third season to Minecraft: Story Mode. The story may be the same cookie-cutter format that most of their games followed, but who's to say that means the game still isn't good?

I would definitely recommend the game if it's still available for purchase, along with Season 1. I haven't played Michonne or Seasons 3 or 4 yet, but I plan to play through them very soon, and I'm sure they're just as great.
